stem: The nurse is evaluating electrolytes in a client with chronic kidney disease (CKD). For each laboratory finding, select the corresponding imbalance and its typical relationship.

rationale.correct: Calcium and phosphorus have an inverse relationship. (r1 & r2) Chronic kidney disease leads to phosphorus retention (High) and decreased Vitamin D activation, leading to low Calcium. Both require monitoring. (r3) Low calcium causes nerve irritability, leading to spasms (Trousseau/Chvostek). (r4) Phosphate binders are mandatory in CKD to lower phosphorus, which in turn helps raise calcium levels.
rationale.incorrect: High calcium (Hypercalcemia) would cause decreased neuromuscular irritability (lethargy/constipation), not spasms.
clinicalPearls: Instruct clients to take phosphate binders with meals or snacks to maximize their effectiveness.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that if one is high, the other is low. In CKD, the See-Saw is tilted: Phosphorus is UP (Kidneys can't excrete) and Calcium is DOWN (Kidneys can't activate Vit D).

mnemonic.title: C-A-T-S
mnemonic.expansion: Convulsions, Arrhythmias, Tetany, Spasms (Signs of Low Calcium).

reviewUnits.heading: Mineral and Bone Disorder in CKD
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor the Ca x Phos product. Maintaining balance is essential to prevent vascular calcification and renal osteodystrophy.
